Owner and master liable in respect of dangerously unsafe ship."management agreement", in relation to a ship, means any agreement (other than a charter-party or a contract of employment) under which the ship is managed, either wholly or in part, by a person other than the owner (whether on behalf of the owner or on behalf of some other person);
Owner and master liable in respect of dangerously unsafe ship."relevant responsibilities" shall be construed in accordance with subsection (6);

Owner and master liable in respect of dangerously unsafe ship.and any reference in this section to going to sea shall, in a case where the service for which a ship is intended consists of going on voyages or excursions that do not involve going to sea, be construed as a reference to going on such a voyage or excursion.

Owner and master liable in respect of dangerously unsafe ship.References in this section to responsibilities being assumed by a person under the terms of a charter-party or management agreement are references to their being so assumed by him whether or not he has entered into a further charter-party or management agreement providing for them to be assumed by some other person.

leaf.margin: Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.

content.leaf: Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.It shall be the duty of the owner of a ship to which this section applies to take all reasonable steps to secure that the ship is operated in a safe manner.
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.This section applies to—
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.any ship registered in the United Kingdom; and
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.any ship which—
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.is registered under the law of any country outside the United Kingdom, and
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.is within the seaward limits of the territorial sea of the United Kingdom while proceeding to or from a port in the United Kingdom,
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.unless the ship would not be so proceeding but for weather conditions or any other unavoidable circumstances.

Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.If the owner of a ship to which this section applies fails to discharge the duty imposed on him by subsection (1), he shall be guilty of an offence and liable—
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.on summary conviction, to a fine not exceeding £50,000;
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.on conviction on indictment, to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years or a fine, or both.
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.Where any such ship—
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.is chartered by demise, or
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.is managed, either wholly or in part, by a person other than the owner under the terms of a management agreement within the meaning of section 30,
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.any reference to the owner of the ship in subsection (1) or (3) above shall be construed as including a reference—
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.to the charterer under the charter by demise, or
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.to any such manager as is referred to in paragraph (b), or
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.(if the ship is both chartered and managed as mentioned above) to both the charterer and any such manager,

Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.and accordingly the reference in subsection (1) to the taking of all reasonable steps shall, in relation to the owner, the charterer or any such manager, be construed as a reference to the taking of all such steps as it is reasonable for him to take in the circumstances of the case.
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.No proceedings for an offence under this section shall be instituted—
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.in England and Wales, except by or with the consent of the Secretary of State or the Director of Public Prosecutions;
Owner liable for unsafe operation of ship.in Northern Ireland, except by or with the consent of the Secretary of State or the Director of Public Prosecutions for Northern Ireland.
Conduct endangering ships, structures or individuals.The following section shall be substituted for section 27 of the [1970 c. 36.] Merchant Shipping Act 1970—

leaf.leaf: Conduct endangering ships, structures or individuals.(3A) Any reference in subsection (1) or (3) above to an operation being likely to result in obstruction or danger to navigation shall, in the case of an operation falling within subsection (1)(a) above, be construed as including a reference to its being likely to result in obstruction or danger to navigation by reason of any use intended to be made of the works in question when constructed, altered or improved.

leaf.margin: Investigation of marine accidents.

content.leaf: Investigation of marine accidents.The Secretary of State shall, for the purpose of the investigation of any such accidents as are mentioned in subsection (2), appoint such number of persons as he may determine to be inspectors of marine accidents, and he shall appoint one of those persons to be Chief Inspector of Marine Accidents.
Investigation of marine accidents.The accidents referred to in subsection (1) are—
Investigation of marine accidents.any accident involving a ship or ship's boat where, at the time of the accident—
Investigation of marine accidents.the ship is registered in the United Kingdom, or
Investigation of marine accidents.the ship, or (in the case of an accident involving a ship's boat) that boat, is within the seaward limits of the territorial sea of the United Kingdom; and
Investigation of marine accidents.such other accidents involving ships or ships' boats as the Secretary of State may determine.

Investigation of marine accidents.The Secretary of State may by regulations make such provision as he considers appropriate with respect to the investigation of any such accidents as are mentioned in subsection (2).
Investigation of marine accidents.Any such regulations may, in particular, make provision—
Investigation of marine accidents.with respect to the definition of "accident" for the purposes of this section and the regulations;
Investigation of marine accidents.imposing requirements as to the reporting of accidents;
Investigation of marine accidents.prohibiting, pending investigation, access to or interference with any ship or ship's boat involved in an accident;

Investigation of marine accidents.authorising any person, so far as may be necessary for the purpose of determining whether an investigation should be carried out, to have access to, examine, remove, test, take measures for the preservation of, or otherwise deal with, any such ship or boat or any other ship or ship's boat;

Investigation of marine accidents.specifying, with respect to the investigation of accidents, the functions of the Chief Inspector of Marine Accidents (which may include the function of determining whether, and if so by whom, particular accidents should be investigated), the functions of other inspectors of marine accidents, and the manner in which any such functions are to be discharged;

Investigation of marine accidents.for the appointment by the Chief Inspector of Marine Accidents, in such circumstances as may be specified in the regulations, of persons to carry out investigations under this section who are not inspectors of marine accidents;
Investigation of marine accidents.for the appointment by any Minister of the Crown of persons to review any findings or conclusions of a person carrying out an investigation under this section;
Investigation of marine accidents.for the procedure to be followed in connection with investigations or reviews under this section;

Investigation of marine accidents.for conferring on persons discharging functions under the regulations who are not inspectors of marine accidents all or any of the powers conferred on an inspector by section 27 of the [1979 c. 39.] Merchant Shipping Act 1979;
Investigation of marine accidents.for the submission to the Secretary of State, and the publication by him, of reports of investigations or reviews under this section;
Investigation of marine accidents.for the publication by the Chief Inspector of Marine Accidents of reports and other information relating to accidents.

Investigation of marine accidents.Regulations under this section may provide for any provisions of the regulations to apply to any specified class or description of incidents or situations which involve, or occur on board, ships or ships' boats but are not accidents for the purposes of the regulations, being a class or description framed by reference to any of the following, namely—
Investigation of marine accidents.the loss or destruction of or serious damage to any ship or structure,
Investigation of marine accidents.the death of or serious injury to any person, or
Investigation of marine accidents.environmental damage,

Investigation of marine accidents.whether actually occurring or not, and (subject to such modifications as may be specified in the regulations) for those provisions to apply in relation to any such incidents or situations as they apply in relation to accidents.

Investigation of marine accidents.Regulations under this section may provide that a contravention of the regulations shall be an offence punishable on summary conviction by a fine not exceeding the statutory maximum and on conviction on indictment by a fine.

Investigation of marine accidents.The Chief Inspector of Marine Accidents, or (as the case may be) inspectors of marine accidents generally, shall discharge such functions in addition to those conferred by or under the preceding provisions of this section as the Secretary of State may determine.

Investigation of marine accidents.Any inspector of marine accidents shall, for the purpose of discharging any functions conferred on him by or under this section, have the powers conferred on an inspector by section 27 of the [1979 c. 39.] Merchant Shipping Act 1979.
Investigation of marine accidents.Nothing in this section shall limit the powers of any authority under sections 530 to 537 of the 1894 Act (removal of wrecks).
Investigation of marine accidents.In this section—

Investigation of marine accidents.references to an accident involving a ship or ship's boat include references to an accident occurring on board a ship or ship's boat (and any reference to a ship or ship's boat involved in an accident shall be construed accordingly); and
Investigation of marine accidents."ship's boat" includes a liferaft.

leaf.margin: Liability and compensation for oil pollution damage.

content.leaf: Liability and compensation for oil pollution damage.The [1971 c. 59.] Merchant Shipping (Oil Pollution) Act 1971 ("the 1971 Act") and the [1974 c. 43.] Merchant Shipping Act 1974 ("the 1974 Act") shall be amended in accordance with Parts I and II of Schedule 4 to this Act (which contain amendments designed to implement provisions of the following Conventions, namely—
Liability and compensation for oil pollution damage.the International Convention on Civil Liability for Oil Pollution Damage 1984; and
Liability and compensation for oil pollution damage.the International Convention on the Establishment of an International Fund for Compensation for Oil Pollution Damage 1984).

Liability and compensation for oil pollution damage.Her Majesty may by Order in Council make such provision as appears to Her Majesty to be appropriate in connection with the implementation of any transitional provisions contained in those Conventions; and any such Order may in particular provide, in relation to occurrences of any description specified in the Order—
Liability and compensation for oil pollution damage.for provisions of the l971 Act or the 1974 Act to have effect —
Liability and compensation for oil pollution damage.to such extent as is so specified, as if Schedule 4 to this Act were not in force, and
Liability and compensation for oil pollution damage.to such extent as is so specified, as if that Schedule were in force;
Liability and compensation for oil pollution damage.for any such provisions to have effect (whether as amended by that Schedule or not) subject to such modifications as are so specified.

leaf.margin: Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.

content.leaf: Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.The Secretary of State may by regulations make, in relation to the transfer of cargo, stores, bunker fuel or ballast between ships while within the seaward limits of the territorial sea of the United Kingdom, such provision as he considers appropriate for preventing pollution, danger to health or to navigation, or hazards to the environment or to natural resources.
Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.Regulations under this section may, in particular, do any of the following things, namely—
Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.prohibit transfers of any specified description or prohibit transfers if, or unless, carried out in specified areas, circumstances or ways;
Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.make provision about—
Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.the design of, and standards to be met by, ships and equipment,

Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.the manning of ships, including the qualifications and experience to be possessed by persons of any specified description employed on board, and

Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.the qualifications and experience to be possessed by persons (whether masters or not) controlling the carrying out of transfers or operations ancillary thereto;

Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.provide for proposed transfers to be notified to and approved by persons appointed by the Secretary of State or another person, and for the supervision of transfers, and the inspection of ships and equipment, by persons so appointed;

Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.for the procedure to be followed in relation to the approval of transfers to be such as may be prescribed by any document specified in the regulations, and

Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.for references in the regulations to any document so specified to operate as references to that document as revised or re-issued from time to time;
Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.provide for the making and keeping of records about ships and equipment, the issuing of certificates, and the furnishing of information;
Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.require the payment of fees determined with the approval of the Treasury;

Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.provide for the granting by the Secretary of State or another person of exemptions from specified provisions of the regulations, on such terms (if any) as the Secretary of State or that other person may specify, and for altering or cancelling exemptions;
Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.limit any provision of the regulations to specified cases or kinds of case.
Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.Regulations under this section may provide—

Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.that a contravention of the regulations shall be an offence punishable on summary conviction by a fine not exceeding £25,000 and on conviction on indictment by imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years or a fine or both;

Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.that any such contravention shall be an offence punishable only on summary conviction by a fine not exceeding £25,000 or such lower amount as is prescribed by the regulations;

Regulation of transfers between ships in territorial waters.that, in such cases as are prescribed by the regulations, such persons as are so prescribed shall each be guilty of an offence created by virtue of paragraph (a) or (b) above.

leaf.margin: Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.

content.leaf: Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.The [1949 c. 74.] Coast Protection Act 1949 shall be amended as follows.

Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.In section 34(1) (restriction of works detrimental to navigation and carried out below high water mark of ordinary spring tides)—

Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.in paragraph (a), for "high water mark of ordinary spring tides" there shall be substituted "the level of mean high water springs"

Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.in paragraph (c), for "low water mark of ordinary spring tides" there shall be substituted "the level of mean low water springs" and

Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.for the words from "so that" onwards there shall be substituted "if the operation (whether while being carried out or subsequently) causes or is likely to result in obstruction or danger to navigation."
Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.The following subsection shall be inserted after section 34(3)—

leaf.leaf: Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.(3A) Any reference in subsection (1) or (3) above to an operation being likely to result in obstruction or danger to navigation shall, in the case of an operation falling within subsection (1)(a) above, be construed as including a reference to its being likely to result in obstruction or danger to navigation by reason of any use intended to be made of the works in question when constructed, altered or improved.

content.leaf: Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.The following subsection shall be inserted after section 34(4)—
Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.In section 36 (enforcement of section 34)—
Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.after subsection (1) there shall be inserted—

leaf.leaf: Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.(1A) Where a person is bound by any condition subject to which any such consent has been given under that section but is not the person to whom the consent was given, then, for the purposes of subsection (1) of this section, he shall not be taken to have failed to comply with the condition unless— (a) he has been served by the Secretary of State with a notice requiring him to comply with the condition within such period (not being less than thirty days) as may be specified in the notice; and (b) he has failed to comply with the condition within that period

content.leaf: Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation. ;
Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.in subsection (2), for "the last foregoing subsection" there shall be substituted "subsection (1) of this section" and

Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.in subsection (4), after "from the person" there shall be inserted "on whom the notice was served under subsection (2) of this section or (if no such notice was served) from the person".
Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.After section 36 insert—
Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.In section 49 (interpretation)—

Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.in subsection (1), in the definitions of "sea" and "seashore", for "the next following subsection" there shall be substituted "subsections (2) and (2A) of this section" and
Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.the following subsection shall be inserted after subsection (2)—

leaf.leaf: Amendments of Coast Protection Act 1949 relating to safety of navigation.(2A) For the purposes of Part II of this Act the expression "sea" includes any part of the sea within the seaward limits of the territorial sea of the United Kingdom, and the expression "seashore" shall be construed accordingly.

leaf.margin: Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.

content.leaf: Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.Where—

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.it appears to the Secretary of State that any harbour authority have, by virtue of any statutory provision, power to license or otherwise regulate operations of any description falling within any of paragraphs (a) to (c) of section 34(1) of the [1949 c. 74.] Coast Protection Act 1949 ("the relevant power"), and

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.he considers it appropriate to do so, he may make regulations providing for section 34 of that Act not to apply to operations of that description in relation to which the relevant power is exercisable and which are carried out within such area or areas falling within the jurisdiction of that harbour authority as may be specified in the regulations ("the prescribed operations"); and, if he does so, the relevant power shall be exercisable by the harbour authority, in relation to the prescribed operations, subject to and in accordance with the following provisions of this section.
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.Regulations made by the Secretary of State under this section with respect to any harbour authority may make provision—
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.in connection with the exercise by the authority of the relevant power in relation to the prescribed operations—
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.for any matter for which provision is made by sections 34(2) to (4A) and 36 of the Coast Protection Act 1949, and

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.for any provision of the regulations made in pursuance of sub-paragraph (i) above or any of paragraphs (b) to (g) below to have effect in addition to or in substitution for any other statutory provision which (apart from the regulations) has effect in that connection;
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.requiring the authority to advertise in such manner as may be specified in the regulations—
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.any application made to them for the grant, in the exercise of the relevant power, of a licence to carry out a prescribed operation, and
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.the grant of any such licence and any conditions subject to which it has been granted,
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.and to give to the Secretary of State such notice of any of those matters as may be so specified;
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.enabling representations to be made with respect to any such application in such manner as may be specified in the regulations;

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.requiring the authority, when determining any such application, to have regard to any representations made in accordance with the regulations so far as touching on any consideration material to the authority's decision on the application;

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.enabling an appeal to the Secretary of State to be brought, by such persons, on such grounds and in such manner as may be specified in the regulations, against—
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.the grant or refusal of any such licence, or
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.any conditions imposed on the grant of any such licence;

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.for the operation of any such licence to be suspended during the period during which such an appeal may be brought and, if such an appeal is brought by a person other than the applicant, until such time (if any) as the authority's decision on the application is affirmed by the Secretary of State;
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.authorising the Secretary of State on such an appeal to do any of the things mentioned in subsection (6)(a) to (c) below;

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.for any statutory provision having effect in relation to the authority to have effect subject to such modifications as appear to the Secretary of State to be necessary or expedient—
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.for the purpose of making provision for any matter for which provision may be made by virtue of any of paragraphs (a) to (g) above, or
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.in consequence of any provision of the regulations made in pursuance of any of those paragraphs.
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.Where—
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.any regulations under this section are in force in relation to a harbour authority, and

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.the authority have determined an application made to them for the grant, in the exercise of the relevant power, of a licence to carry out a prescribed operation, and
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.no appeal has been brought (whether under the regulations or otherwise) in respect of their determination of the application, but

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.the Secretary of State considers that it would be appropriate in the interests of the safety of navigation for the application to be redetermined by him,

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.the Secretary of State may, within the period of 60 days beginning with the date of the authority's determination, serve a notice on the authority requiring them to furnish him with written particulars of their determination, and with any documents in their possession relating to the application, in order that he may redetermine the application.
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.Where the Secretary of State serves a notice under subsection (3) in respect of any application—

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.the Secretary of State shall serve a copy of that notice on the applicant and shall, in such manner as he thinks fit, advertise the fact that the application is to be redetermined by him; and

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.the operation of any licence granted by the authority in pursuance of the application shall be suspended until such time (if any) as the authority's decision to grant the licence is affirmed by the Secretary of State under subsection (6).

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.The Secretary of State shall, when redetermining any application, have regard to any representations made to him by persons appearing to him to be likely to be affected by the operation to which the application relates where those representations have been made to him within the period of 30 days beginning with the date (or, as the case may be, the latest date) of the publication of any advertisement published in pursuance of subsection (4)(a).
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.Where the Secretary of State redetermines an application, he may (according to the circumstances of the case)—
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.direct the harbour authority to grant either—
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.a licence free from conditions, or
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.a licence subject to such conditions as are specified in the direction,
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.as he thinks fit;
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.direct the harbour authority to cancel any licence granted by them in pursuance of the application; or
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.affirm the harbour authority's determination of the application.

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.Any direction given by the Secretary of State under subsection (6)(a) shall be a direction requiring the authority in question to grant such a licence as is mentioned in sub-paragraph (i) or (ii) of that provision either—
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.in the form in which it was originally applied for by the applicant, or
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.in that form but subject to such modifications as are specified in the direction,

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.as the Secretary of State thinks fit; but where the Secretary of State proposes to specify any modifications under paragraph (b) above which appear to him to be capable of resulting in any substantial interference with navigation—
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.he shall take such steps as appear to him to be reasonably practicable for informing persons likely to be concerned, and
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.shall not so specify those modifications unless there has elapsed such period for consideration of, and comment upon, them as he thinks reasonable.

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.The power of the Secretary of State to make any regulations under this section with respect to any harbour authority shall be exercisable by him either—
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.on the application of the harbour authority, or
Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.of his own motion after consulting the authority.

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.On each occasion when a harbour authority grant a licence in the exercise of any such power as is mentioned in subsection (1) (whether they do so in pursuance of the preceding provisions of this section or not) they shall furnish the Hydrographer of the Navy—

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.before the operation to which the licence relates has been begun, with written particulars of the operation and with a plan showing where it is to be carried out, and

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.once the operation has been carried out, with a notification of that fact, and with such plans and additional information relating to the completed operation as he may require for the purpose of determining whether, and if so what, changes should be made to any chart or other publication produced under his superintendence.

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.It shall be the duty of any harbour authority to whom the Secretary of State gives a direction under or by virtue of this section to give effect to the direction.

Licensing of tidal works by harbour authorities.In this section "licence" includes a consent or permission and references to the grant of a licence accordingly include references to the giving of a consent or permission.
Protection of shipping interests

leaf.margin: Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.

content.leaf: Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.Part III of the [1974 c. 43.] Merchant Shipping Act 1974 (protection of shipping and trading interests) shall be amended as follows.
Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.In section 14 (foreign action affecting shipping), the following subsection shall be substituted for subsection (1)—

leaf.leaf: Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.(1) The Secretary of State may exercise the powers conferred by this section if he is satisfied that— (a) a foreign government, or (b) persons purporting to exercise governing authority over any territory outside the United Kingdom, or (c) any agency or authority of a foreign government or of such persons,have adopted, or propose to adopt, measures or practices concerning or affecting any shipping services which— (i) are damaging or threaten to damage the shipping or trading interests of the United Kingdom, or (ii) are damaging or threaten to damage the shipping or trading interests of another State,and, in the latter case, the Secretary of State is satisfied that action under this section would be in fulfilment of the obligations of the United Kingdom to that other State or would be appropriate in view of any arrangements made between Her Majesty's Government and the government of that other State.

content.leaf: Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.The following subsection shall be substituted for section 14(3)—
Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.In section 14(4) (orders under subsection (3)), for "subsection (1)(a)" substitute "subsection (1)(i)".

Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.In section 14(5) (directions by Secretary of State), for "charges imposed under subsection (3)(d) above" there shall be substituted "any charge, tax or duty imposed under subsection (3)(d) or (e) above".
Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.The following subsections shall be substituted for section 14(11) and (11A)—

leaf.leaf:
Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.(11) In this section— (a) "foreign government" means the government of any State other than the United Kingdom; (b) references to an agency or authority of a foreign government or of such persons as are mentioned in subsection (1)(b) above include references to any undertaking appearing to the Secretary of State to be, or to be acting on behalf of, an undertaking which is in effect owned or controlled (directly or indirectly) by a State other than, or by a territory outside, the United Kingdom; (c) "shipping services" means services provided by means of ships, and includes the carriage of goods or passengers by sea, cable laying, dredging, and services provided by offshore support vessels; and (d) references to ships are to ships of any registration.
(11A) A recital in an order under this section that the persons who have adopted, or propose to adopt, the measures or practices in question are— (a) a foreign government, or (b) such persons as are mentioned in subsection (1)(b) above, or (c) an agency or authority of a foreign government or of such persons,shall be conclusive.

content.leaf: Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.In section 15 (parliamentary control of orders under section 14)—
Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.at the beginning of each of subsections (1) and (2) there shall be inserted "Subject to subsection (2A) below,"
Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.after subsection (2) there shall be inserted—

leaf.leaf: Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.(2A) Subsections (1) and (2) above do not apply to an order under the said subsection (3) which is made for the purpose only of implementing any Community obligation.

content.leaf: Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974. ; and
Amendments of Part III of Merchant Shipping Act 1974.in subsection (4), after "recites" there shall be inserted "that it is made as mentioned in subsection (2A) above, or".

Section 13.Registration of Fishing Vessels: Supplementary Provisions
Interpretation
In this Schedule—
"declaration of British character" means a declaration, in such form as may be prescribed, relating to the eligibility of a fishing vessel to be registered as a British fishing vessel;
"regulations" means regulations made under section 13;
"relevant statutory provision" means any provision of this Part or of regulations;
"specified" means specified in regulations.
Regulations: general provisions
Regulations may make provision—

for the persons by whom and the manner in which applications in connection with registration are to be made (including provision limiting the persons who may apply for registration, whether by reference to residence or place of business or otherwise);

for the information and evidence to be provided in connection with such applications and for such supplementary information or evidence as may be required by any authority specified in the regulations for the purpose to be so provided, and for the production, in connection with such applications, of declarations of British character;
for the registration of vessels as vessels to which the provisions of this Part relating to transfers by bill of sale and the registration of mortgages do not apply;
for the issue of certificates of registration (including temporary certificates), their production and surrender;
for the marking of registered vessels;
for the period for which the registration of a vessel is to remain effective without renewal;
for matters arising out of the expiration or termination of registration (including the removal of marks and the cancellation of certificates);
for declarations of British character to be produced to the Secretary of State, as respects registered vessels, at specified intervals or at the request of the Secretary of State;
for the payment of fees determined with the approval of the Treasury;
excluding from registration, or from any provision of the regulations, any specified class or description of vessel;
for the manner in which notices or other documents required or authorised to be given or served by virtue of any relevant statutory provision are to be given or served;
for prescribing anything which is authorised to be prescribed under this Part;
for any of the provisions of Part I of the 1894 Act to have effect in relation to the registration of fishing vessels subject to such modifications (if any) as may be specified;
for any other matters relating to the establishment and maintenance of the register (including its inspection).
Provisional registration
Regulations may make provision—

for fishing vessels acquired outside the United Kingdom which are eligible to be registered as British fishing vessels to be provisionally registered as such pending their registration in the register;
for any such provisional registration to terminate in specified circumstances (including failure to comply with requirements imposed by or under the regulations).
Transfers of registration
Regulations may make provision with respect to the transfer to the register of—
fishing vessels to which section 13(3) applies where those vessels are eligible to be registered as British fishing vessels, and
undischarged mortgages affecting those vessels,

and with respect to matters consequential on the termination of the registration of fishing vessels under any of the enactments specified in section 13(2) (including vessels which are not transferred to the register).
Any such regulations may make provision—
for any of the matters specified in sub-paragraphs (a), (b) and (i) of paragraph 2;
for applications under sections 19(3) and 20(1) to be treated, in cases where those provisions apply by virtue of section 13(4), as applications for registration of the vessels in question;

for the issue of certificates of registration under this Part (including temporary certificates) and for the surrender of certificates of registration issued under any of the enactments specified in section 13(2);

for preserving the effect of entries in any register kept under either of the enactments specified in section 13(2)(a) and (c) so far as those entries relate to undischarged mortgages affecting vessels which are not transferred to the register kept under this Part.
Nothing in this paragraph prejudices the generality of paragraph 2.
Offences
Regulations may provide for the creation of offences and their punishment on summary conviction in any of the following cases—
where a person with intent to deceive, uses, or lends to or allows to be used by another, a certificate of registration, whether in force or not;
where a person required by regulations to ensure that any requirement of the regulations as to the marking of a fishing vessel is satisfied fails to ensure that that requirement is satisfied;
where a person required by regulations to surrender a certificate of registration fails without reasonable excuse to surrender the certificate.
Any such regulations shall—
in the case of an offence created by virtue of sub-paragraph (1)(a), provide for the offence to be punishable with a fine not exceeding the fifth level on the standard scale; and
in the case of an offence created by virtue of sub-paragraph (1)(b) or (c), provide for it to be punishable with a fine not exceeding the third level on the standard scale.

Regulations providing for the creation of an offence by virtue of sub-paragraph (1)(b) shall provide that it shall be a defence for a person charged with the offence to prove that he took all reasonable precautions and exercised all due diligence to avoid the commission of the offence.
Operation of regulations in territorial waters
Regulations may provide for any of their provisions to extend to the territorial sea of the United Kingdom.
Discharge of functions by persons appointed by Secretary of State
The Secretary of State may appoint persons to discharge such functions in connection with—
applications for registration, or
the issue, production or surrender of certificates of registration,
as he may specify; and regulations may provide for references to the Secretary of State in any relevant statutory provision to be read as, or as including, references to any person so appointed.
Sub-paragraph (1) does not authorise the appointment of any person to determine applications for registration.
Construction of references in other enactments to fishing vessels excluded from registration

References in any statutory provision (apart from section 2(1)(c)) to fishing vessels excluded from registration by regulations under section 13 shall be construed as references to fishing vessels which, being eligible to be registered under this Part by virtue of section 14, are excluded from registration by such regulations (and are not registered under the law of any country outside the United Kingdom).
Section 21.Mortgages of Registered Fishing Vessels
Interpretation
In this Schedule—
"mortgage" shall be construed in accordance with paragraph 2(2) below;
"registered mortgage" means a mortgage registered in pursuance of paragraph 2(3) below; and
"registered vessel" means a vessel registered otherwise than in pursuance of paragraph 2(c) of Schedule 2.
Mortgages of registered vessels
Any registered vessel or share in a registered vessel may be made a security for the repayment of a loan or the discharge of any other obligation.
The instrument creating any such security (referred to in this Schedule as a mortgage) shall be in such form as is prescribed or approved by the Secretary of State.
Where a mortgage executed in accordance with sub-paragraph (2) is produced to the Secretary of State, he shall—
register the mortgage by causing it to be recorded in the register, and
endorse on it the fact that it has been recorded, together with the date and time when it was recorded.
Mortgages shall be registered under sub-paragraph (3) in the order in which they are produced to the Secretary of State for the purposes of registration.
Priority of registered mortgages

Where two or more mortgages are registered in respect of the same vessel or share, the priority of the mortgagees between themselves shall (subject to paragraph 4) be determined by the order in which the mortgages were registered (and not by reference to any other matter).
Notices by intending mortgagees
Where any person who is an intending mortgagee under a proposed mortgage of—
a registered vessel, or
a share in a registered vessel,

notifies the Secretary of State in writing of the interest which it is intended that he should have under the proposed mortgage, the Secretary of State shall cause that interest to be recorded in the register.
Where any person who is an intending mortgagee under a proposed mortgage of—
a fishing vessel which is not for the time being a registered vessel, or
a share in any such vessel,

notifies the Secretary of State in writing of the interest which it is intended that he should have under the proposed mortgage and furnishes him with such particulars of that vessel as may be prescribed, the Secretary of State—

content.leaf: Section 58(4).Transitional Provisions and Savings
The amendments and repeals made by this Act do not—
(unless an Order in Council under section 56 of this Act, or under any other enactment, so provides) extend to any country outside the United Kingdom; or
affect any Order in Council providing for the extension of any enactments to any such country.
This paragraph shall have effect in relation to any relevant overseas territory to which the provisions of sections 2 to 7 of this Act have not been extended by an Order in Council under section 56.
Where—

by virtue of section 2(2) of the 1894 Act (obligation to register British ship) as in force in any such territory, any ship is (apart from this paragraph) a British ship that is not to be recognised as such, but
the ship is a British ship by virtue of section 2 of this Act,
the ship shall nevertheless be recognised as a British ship for the purposes of the Merchant Shipping Acts as in force in that territory.
Where—
by virtue of section 2(2) of the 1894 Act as in force in any such territory, any ship is a British ship that is not to be recognised as such, and
the ship is not a British ship by virtue of section 2 of this Act,
the ship shall, notwithstanding section 2(3) of that Act (as so in force), not be liable to detention under that provision.
Where—
any ship is not wholly owned by such persons as are mentioned in section 1 of the 1894 Act (qualification for owning British ships) as in force in any such territory, but
the ship is a British ship by virtue of section 2 of this Act,

the ship shall nevertheless be recognised as a British ship for the purposes of the Merchant Shipping Acts as in force in that territory, and the following provisions of the 1894 Act (as so in force), namely—
section 69 (penalty for unduly assuming British character), and
section 71 (penalty for acquiring ownership if unqualified),
shall not apply in relation to the ship.
If the Secretary of State by order made by statutory instrument so provides, no registration of a fishing boat shall be effected—
under Part IV of the 1894 Act, or
under the [1886 c. 53.] Sea Fishing Boats (Scotland) Act 1886,
during such period not exceeding one month and ending with the commencement of Part II of this Act as is specified in the order.

Section 4(6) of this Act shall not have effect at any time before the commencement of Part II of this Act, and shall not affect the operation of section 13(3) of this Act in relation to fishing vessels which are registered under Part I of the 1894 Act immediately before the commencement of Part II of this Act.

In section 72(1) of the 1894 Act as amended by Schedule 1 to this Act (liabilities of unregistered ships), the reference to Part I of that Act shall, in relation to any time before the end of the period referred to in section 13(3)(b) of this Act, be construed as including a reference to Part IV of that Act.
